description.narrative: IFC is considering a US$12 million loan in local currency to the Municipality of San Jose (the municipality or MSJ) to finance (i) the upgrade of three urban corridors with a total of 2.7 kilometers across the city: Transversal 24 (T24), Calle 33 and Calle 78, and (ii) rehabilitation and expansion of the rainwater drainage system of the municipality with a total of approximately 3.8 kilometers in the areas where flood frequently occurs.

The overall expected development impact of this engagement is the following: Project Level Outcomes i) Improve quality and access to urban infrastructure services. These investments are part of the MSJ's revitalization master plan which is oriented to stop urban sprawl in its downtown area, increase the city center density, and improve the overall city's resilience to shocks derived from economic downturn and climate change. The plan delivers impact to the 340 thousand inhabitants of MSJ's metropolitan area and the approximately 2 million people living in the city's periphery. The project will enable better delivery of public services (public transportation and mobility alternatives, connectivity and sewerage). The project will contribute to access to new jobs, business and urban services as the rehabilitation of urban corridors is intended to act as a cluster of economic development. The current inhabitants of the project's catchment area are the main beneficiaries of the improved quality of the services. ii) Increase municipal government tax revenue base and collection levels. The project is expected to improve the municipality fiscal sustainability by attracting new permanent inhabitants (increasing tax base) and increasing tax revenue collections from (i) property value around the revitalized corridors; and (ii) licenses and fees related to real-estate commercial and housing development. Market Creation Outcomes i) Increased access to capital markets. The project is the first financing transaction outside the local market and will contribute to demonstrate the viability of municipal infrastructure financing to international investors allowing the municipality to tap into new sources and more flexible instruments. MSJ can be an example of how middle and small size cities can improve financial resilience diversifying funding sources and reduce reliance on inadequate local financing, international bond markets and central government transfers.
